channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: Six new cases and further death reported for 2 May
item.description: There are six new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand and one further death today, while two clusters have also closed today.

item.title: Covid-19: Live updates from New Zealand and around the world on 2 May
item.description: Police are set to prosecute more than 100 people for breaches of alert level three. Follow RNZ's blog for the latest.

item.title: Another 50 cargo flights a week, to and from New Zealand
item.description: Another 50 flights of air freight have been added each week to lift the volumes of goods going in and out of the country.

item.title: Bigger bubble with Australia, Asia, and Pacific mooted
item.description: A transtasman bubble could eventually be extended to include Asian and Pacific countries that have been successful in fighting Covid-19, epidemiologist Professor Michael Baker says.

item.title: Few level 3 business breaches despite almost 1000 complaints this week - association
item.description: Few businesses are breaching pandemic rules, an employers' association says, despite 991 complaints being lodged against businesses since alert level 3 began this week.

item.title: Man missing from Porirua since March found dead
item.description: The body of a 49-year-old reported missing from Porirua in March has been found.

item.title: Hipkins announces $20m fund to help tertiary students to learn online
item.description: A $20 million fund has been announced to help tertiary students access digital devices and the internet to continue learning during Covid-19 disruptions.

item.title: University students continue to pay for rooms inaccessible in lockdown
item.description: New Zealand's student body president says universities need to show humanity and stop charging students for hostel rooms they are not able to use.

item.title: Punters move online as Lotto, SkyCity report increased activity in lockdown
item.description: The Problem Gambling Foundation is concerned more New Zealanders are logging into online lotto and gambling sites during the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: 'Beggars belief' that PPE would fail - Waitemata DHB nurse
item.description: A nurse at Waitemata DHB - where three staff have contracted Covid-19 - says its use of PPE has been inadequate.

item.title: Auckland's iconic Mercury Plaza sign back for a spell
item.description: The retro neon sign that lit up Auckland's beloved Asian food hall Mercury Plaza has been redeployed for a worthy cause - a lockdown game of scrabble.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 1 May
item.description: The first weekend in alert level 3 is here. House parties were one of the many breaches reported this week and the government is warning NZers to stick to their bubbles.

item.title: West Coast's leaders want region's lockdown rules relaxed
item.description: One West Coast mayor - Bruce Smith - says the alert level 3 restrictions are based on fear, not facts.

item.title: Two seriously injured after police chase in New Plymouth
item.description: An eyewitness says a car being chased by police in New Plymouth was travelling at least 100 kilometres an hour before it t-boned into another vehicle after running a red light.

item.title: Sightings of another whale in Wellington
item.description: Wellington is becoming the playground capital for sea life following another whale spotting today.

item.title: Capping off 11 years of university study locked down
item.description: After studying for over a third of his life, Wesley Webb didn't feel like mooching around home on what would have been his graduation day.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world
item.description: Grant Robertson has warned NZs not to hold parties at home during level three, as Covid-19 can spread easily at such events. See how the rest of the day's events unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Covid-19: Power company's price increase delayed
item.description: A power company says it has delayed a price increase that was planned to take effect during lockdown, but it doesn't appear to have told customers.
